The '''Institute of Contemporary Arts (ICA) Singapore''' is the curatorial division of [[LASALLE College of the Arts]], dedicated to supporting innovative and emerging creative practices. Focusing on [[art]] and [[design]] from the present, it provides an active site for contemporary [[culture]] in [[Singapore]]. It comprises five galleries that span a total of 1,500 square metres, one of the largest spaces devoted to contemporary art in Singapore. It engages local and international audiences in critical viewing and discussion through a diverse programme of exhibitions, projects, publications and events.
The ICA Singapore provides a cultural and educational tool for students and the wider public to advance their knowledge and appreciation of the contemporary local, regional and international arts.
==History== The Dr Earl Lu Gallery was established by LASALLE College of the Arts in 1986,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Yap|first1=June|title=A Brief History of the Singapore Visual Arts Scene|journal=Singapore's Visual Artists|date=2016|volume=Singapore: National Arts Council.}}</ref> in recognition of a major contribution of artworks by [[philanthropist]] and artist Dr [[Earl Lu]], it presented exhibitions of traditional and contemporary arts, often with a focus on practices from [[Asia]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Yap|first1=June|title=A Brief History of the Singapore Visual Arts Scene|journal=Singapore's Visual Artists|date=2016|volume=Singapore: National Arts Council.}}</ref> From 2001 to 2004, under the directorship of Binghui Huangfu, the gallery worked closely with LASALLE’s Contemporary Asian Art Centre, a research facility directed by T.K. Sabapathy that sought to advance knowledge and collaboration between artists across Asia through dialogue, research and publications. In 2004, Dr Earl Lu Gallery was renamed the '''Institute of Contemporary Arts Singapore''' and repositioned as a centre of Singapore and international contemporary art.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tan|first1=Eugene|title=Art in Singapore and the Institute of Contemporary Arts Singapore|journal=Perspectives|date=July 2007|volume=Hong Kong: Asia Art Archive|url=http://www.aaa.org.hk/Diaaalogue/Details/31|accessdate=18 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128050814/http://www.aaa.org.hk/Diaaalogue/Details/31|archivedate=28 January 2016|df=}}</ref> In 2007, the institute moved along with LASALLE College of the Arts from the Goodman Road campus to a new campus on McNally Street, where it is based today.<ref>{{cite web|title=LASALLE College of the Arts|url=http://www.mimoa.eu/projects/Singapore/Singapore/LASALLE%20college%20of%20the%20arts/?abvar3|website=Mimoa: Mi Modern Architecture|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref>
Since its establishment, the ICA Singapore has presented exhibitions of international [[contemporary art]]. These include solo exhibitions by [[Yeo Hwee Bin]] (2000),<ref>{{cite web|title=Yeo Hwee Bin: Pioneer Sculptor|url=http://www.aaa.org.hk/Collection/Details/2783|website=Collection|publisher=Hong Kong: Asia Art Archive|accessdate=20 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160630180942/http://www.aaa.org.hk/Collection/Details/2783|archivedate=30 June 2016|df=}}</ref> [[On Kawara]] (2004), [[Antony Gormley]] (2005), Lim Tzay Chuen (2005),<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tan|first1=Eugene|title=Art in Singapore and the Institute of Contemporary Arts Singapore|journal=Perspectives|date=July 2007|volume=Hong Kong: Asia Art Archive|url=http://www.aaa.org.hk/Diaaalogue/Details/31|accessdate=18 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128050814/http://www.aaa.org.hk/Diaaalogue/Details/31|archivedate=28 January 2016|df=}}</ref> [[Roberto Chabet]] (2011),<ref>{{cite web|title=Philippine Art off to a Rousing Start in Singapore for 2011|url=http://www.philippine-embassy.org.sg/news/2011/01/philippine-art-off-to-rousing-start-in-singapore-for-2011/|website=Embassy of the Philippines|accessdate=27 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160629221713/http://www.philippine-embassy.org.sg/news/2011/01/philippine-art-off-to-rousing-start-in-singapore-for-2011/|archivedate=29 June 2016|df=}}</ref> Ian Woo (2011),<ref>{{cite web|title=Ian Woo: Biography|url=http://ian-woo.com/bio/|website=Tomio Koyama Gallery|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref> Jeremy Sharma (2012)<ref>{{cite web|title=Apropos: Jeremy Sharma|url=http://www.artsrepublic.sg/apropos/|website=Arts Republic|publisher=Singapore.|accessdate=30 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160916132134/http://www.artsrepublic.sg/apropos/|archivedate=16 September 2016|df=}}</ref> Milenko Prvacki (2012),<ref>{{cite news|last1=Huang|first1=Lijie|title=Prvacki’s Progress|agency=Singapore.|publisher=The Straits Times|date=2012}}</ref> Shubigi Rao (2013),<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chia|first1=Adeline|title=Singapore Gallery Crawl: Shubigi Rao, Marina Cruz and Thukral & Tagra|journal=BLOUIN ARTINFO|date=21 March 2013|url=http://sea.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/881668/singapore-gallery-crawl-shubigi-rao-marina-cruz-and-thukral|accessdate=30 April 2016}}</ref> [[Tang Da Wu]] (2013),<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Teh|first1=David|title=Tang Da Wu|journal=Artforum|date=2013|url=http://artforum.com/index.php?pn=picks&id=40099&view=print|accessdate=5 May 2016}}</ref> Jack Tan (2015),<ref>{{cite web|title=Jack Tan: How to do Things with Rules|url=http://sagg.info/event/jack-tan-how-to-do-things-with-rules/|website=Singapore Art Gallery Guide|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> Marco Fusinato (2015)<ref>{{cite web|title=Marco Fusinato: Constellations|url=https://www.noisesingapore.com/Happenings/2015/8/15/Marco-Fusinato-Constellations/|website=Noise Singapore|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> and [[Ana Prvacki|Ana Prvački]] (2015–16).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wu|first1=Daven|title=Finding comfort in an uncomfortable imagination: Ana Prvački at ICA Singapore|url=http://www.wallpaper.com/art/ana-prvaki-at-institute-of-contemporary-arts-singapore|website=Wallpaper|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> Group exhibitions include ''Text & Subtext: International Contemporary Asian Women Artists Exhibition'' (2000), ''Sight and Sight: Translating Cultures'' (2003),<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Seng|first1=Yu Jin|title=Reconnecting the Past / Notes on an Art Collection|journal=The Next Chapter, Forays into LASALLE’s Permanent Collection|date=2009|volume=Singapore: Institute of Contemporary Arts Singapore}}</ref> ''Lost to the Future: Contemporary Art from Central Asia'' (2013),<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Whittaker|first1=Iona|title=Found for the Future?|journal=Randian|date=9 January 2014|url=http://www.randian-online.com/np_review/found-for-the-future/|accessdate=10 May 2016}}</ref> ''Sound: Latitudes and Attitudes'' (2014),<ref>{{cite web|title=Sound: Latitudes and Attitudes|url=http://www.themuse.com.sg/2014/01/show-sound-latitudes-and-attitudes/|website=Muse|accessdate=10 May 2016}}</ref> ''Countershadows (tactics in evasion)'' (2014),<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Quek|first1=Bruce|title=Dust and Shadows|journal=Randian|date=13 November 2014|url=http://www.randian-online.com/np_review/dust-and-shadows/|accessdate=10 May 2016}}</ref> ''Artists Imagine a Nation: SG50: Pictures of People and Places from the Collections of [[Koh Seow Chuan]] and Friends'' (2015),<ref>{{cite news|last1=Martin|first1=Mayo|title=First SG50 Visual Art Exhibition up at LASALLE|url=http://beta2.todayonline.com/blogs/forartssake/first-sg50-visual-art-exhibition-lasalle|accessdate=10 May 2016|agency=TODAY. Singapore|date=17 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161012004626/http://beta2.todayonline.com/blogs/forartssake/first-sg50-visual-art-exhibition-lasalle|archivedate=12 October 2016|df=}}</ref> ''Rendez-Vous'' (2015)<ref>{{cite news|last1=Said|first1=Nabilah|title=Herbal Drink Jamu Featured in Exhibition Showcasing Emerging Artists|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/arts/herbal-drink-jamu-featured-in-exhibition-showcasing-emerging-artists|accessdate=10 May 2016|agency=The Straits Times. Singapore|date=16 June 2015}}</ref> and ''Sous la Lune/Beneath the Moon'' (2015–16).<ref>{{cite web|title=Sous la Lune/Beneath the Moon: Extra Mural Project|url=http://www.palaisdetokyo.com/en/exhibition/beneath-moonsous-la-lune-hors-les-murs|publisher=Palais de Tokyo. Paris|accessdate=10 May 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118093033/http://www.palaisdetokyo.com/en/exhibition/beneath-moonsous-la-lune-hors-les-murs|archivedate=18 January 2016|df=}}</ref>
Past directors of the ICA Singapore include Binghui Huangfu (1996–2003), Eugene Tan (2003–08) and Charles Merewether (2010–13). The current director of ICA Singapore is Melbourne-born curator Bala Starr.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chandrasekaran|first1=S|title=Exhibition-making is a Learning Environment|journal=Praxis Press|date=2014|volume=LASALLE College of the Arts|url=http://www.lasalle.edu.sg/wp-content/uploads/ffa_publication_2014_praxis-press.pdf|accessdate=10 May 2016}}</ref>
==Controversies==
In February 2016, two items that were part of the group show "Fault-lines: Disparate and desperate intimacies" were removed from artist [[Loo Zihan]]'s installation "Queer objects: An archive for the future".<ref>{{cite news |first = Jian Xuan|last = Lee|authorlink = |coauthors = |title = Sex objects removed from art show|url = http://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/arts/sex-objects-removed-from-art-show|work = The Straits Times|date = 16 February 2016|accessdate = 16 February 2016}}</ref> This action was agreed after discussion between ICA Singapore staff, curator Wong Binghao, and Loo Zihan, and was due to the nature of the objects, which could potentially be considered offensive to some members of the public. The items were a penis sheath and a butt plug. The ICA Singapore, curator and artist emphasised that the decision was taken to make the exhibition accessible to all, including students of the LASALLE College of the Arts, half of whom are under 18 years old.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Facebook|url = http://www.facebook.com/ICASgalleries/notifications/?section=activity_feed&subsection=mention&target_story=S%3A_I100000600513049%3A1228728023823870|website = www.facebook.com|access-date = 2016-02-19}}</ref>

[[File:Ringold Alley, San Francisco.jpg|thumb|[[San Francisco South of Market Leather History Alley]] on Ringold Street]] {{Coord|37.7739571|-122.4125042|display=title}} The '''LGBTQ and Leather Cultural District''' is a cultural district in [[San Francisco]]'s [[South of Market, San Francisco|South of Market]] (SOMA) neighborhood commemorating the history and culture of the [[leather subculture]] active in the area for approximately half a century. The [[San Francisco Board of Supervisors]] established the district in June, 2018<ref>{{cite web|last=Sabatini |first=Joshua |url=http://www.sfexaminer.com/sf-expands-cultural-districts-include-somas-gay-leather-community/ |title=SF expands cultural districts to include SoMa’s gay and leather community - by j_sabatini - May 1, 2018 - The San Francisco Examiner |publisher=Sfexaminer.com |date=2018 |accessdate=2018-05-02}}</ref> and a ribbon cutting was held outside [[The Stud (bar)|The Stud]] on 9th St., the city's oldest gay bar.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2018/06/21/leather-community-celebrates-designated-district-at-this-years-sf-pride/ |title=Leather Community Celebrates Designated District At This Year’s SF Pride « CBS San Francisco |publisher=Sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com |date=2018-05-24 |accessdate=2018-06-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Sabatini |first=Joshua |url=http://www.sfexaminer.com/sf-expands-cultural-districts-include-somas-gay-leather-community/ |title=SF expands cultural districts to include SoMa’s gay and leather community - by j_sabatini - May 1, 2018 - The San Francisco Examiner |publisher=Sfexaminer.com |date=2018-05-01 |accessdate=2018-06-24}}</ref>
The area is bounded approximately by Howard St. on the northwest, 7th St. on the northeast, I-80 on the east and US 101 on the south. There is also an exclave between 5th and 6th streets, Harrison and Bryant.<ref>{{cite web|author=by AdminSFLD |url=http://leatheralliance.org/sfleatherdistrict/2018/05/30/map-of-district/ |title=Map of District – Leather and LGBTQ Cultural District |publisher=Leatheralliance.org |date=2018-05-30 |accessdate=2018-06-24}}</ref> It includes the [[San Francisco South of Market Leather History Alley]], which opened in 2017.<ref>http://www.artandarchitecture-sf.com/ringold-alleys-leather-memoir.html</ref><ref name="Jewish">{{cite web|last=Paull |first=Laura |url=https://www.jweekly.com/2018/06/21/honoring-gay-leather-culture-with-art-installation-in-soma-alleyway/ |title=Honoring gay leather culture with art installation in SoMa alleyway – J |publisher=Jweekly.com |date= |accessdate=2018-06-23}}</ref>
The aim of the district is to "honor and commemorate the people, places and institutions that gave South of Market its distinctive culture and appeal, and would also help protect the remaining businesses and spaces, and sustain the people who live, work and recreate there."<ref>[https://docs.google.com/document/d/1j-10kqxOWKt0tnx6fgnZRD3Kk0T7yJF4kbnu4BxFDNM/ "Introduction to the Leather and LGBTQ Cultural District Project", Leather and LGBTQ Cultural District Project, June 2018]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.sfleatherdistrict.org LGBTQ and Leather Cultural District website]

page.title: Letters Writ by a Turkish Spy

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Letters Writ by a Turkish Spy''''' ({{lang-fr|L'Espion Turc}}) is an eight-volume collection of fictional letters claiming to have been written by an [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] spy named "Mahmut",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/books/review/2007/01/25/stuart/|title=Herbivore vs. carnivore|first=Laura|last=Miller|date=2007-01-25|publisher=[[Salon.com]]|accessdate=2007-01-25}}</ref> in the French court of [[Louis XIV]].
==Authorship and publication== [[File:Giovanni-Paolo-Marana-Espion-turc MG 9430.tif|thumb|Tome 4. Portrait of Mahomet "The impostor"]]
It is agreed that the first volume of this work was written by [[Giovanni Paolo Marana]] (1642-1693), a [[Genoa|Genoese]] political refugee to the French court of [[Louis XIV]].<ref>Paula R. Backscheider, Catherine Ingrassia, 2005, ''A companion to the eighteenth-century English novel and culture'', page 55</ref><ref name="Ballaster207">Rosalind Ballaster, 2005, ''Fables of the East: selected tales, 1662-1785'', page 207</ref> The first volume (102 letters) was published in several parts between 1684 and 1686 in both Italian and in a French translation.<ref name="Betts">C. J. Betts, 1984, ''Early deism in France'', pages 97-8</ref> They were translated by [[William Bradshaw (writer)|William Bradshaw]] into English in 1687 under the supervision of [[Robert Midgley]] who owned the copyright of the work.<ref name="Ballaster207"/> The remaining seven volumes appeared first in English between 1691 and 1694, prefaced with a letter claiming that they were translated from a discovered Italian manuscript.<ref name="Ballaster207"/> A French edition of the last seven volumes (with the first) was published in 1696-7 and asserting that it was a translation from the English.<ref name="Ballaster208">Rosalind Ballaster, 2005, ''Fables of the East: selected tales, 1662-1785'', page 208</ref> The eight volumes contain 644 letters.<ref name="Betts"/>
There has long been a controversy as to the authorship of the volumes subsequent to Marana's first. They have been attributed to many writers, most notably Robert Midgley and William Bradshaw who produced the English translation.<ref name="Ballaster208"/><ref name="Backscheider58">Paula R. Backscheider, Catherine Ingrassia, 2005, ''A companion to the eighteenth-century English novel and culture'', page 58</ref> However, given the similarities between the letters, and the stylistic coherence of the whole series, the likeliest author is Marana himself.<ref name="Betts"/><ref name="Rosalind Ballaster 2005, page 145">Rosalind Ballaster, 2005, ''Fabulous orients: fictions of the East in England, 1662-1785'', page 145</ref> Marana may have had difficulty in getting the later volumes published in France and turned to England to secure their continuing appearance.<ref name="Ballaster208"/>
The work was popular throughout the 18th century and went through fifteen complete editions by 1801.<ref name="Ballaster208"/> [[Daniel Defoe]] was attracted to the deist rationalist sympathies of the purported spy; his ''Continuation of Turkish Letters Writ by a Turkish Spy in Paris'' (1718) extended the narrator's account from 1687 to 1693.<ref name="Rosalind Ballaster 2005, page 145"/>
==Content== The volumes contain fictional letters written by one "Mahmut the Arabian."<ref>Paula R. Backscheider, Catherine Ingrassia, 2005, ''A companion to the eighteenth-century English novel and culture'', page 56</ref> The letters cover the period of 1637 to 1682 in France, from the last years of the Regency of [[Anne of Austria]] and [[Cardinal Richelieu]] through the long reign of Louis XIV and his minister [[Cardinal Mazarin]].<ref name="Ballaster208"/> The Letters form a rambling journal of gossip on current politics and satire on society.<ref>Martha Pike Conant, 2009, ''The Oriental Tale in England in the Eighteenth Century'', page 158</ref> Mahmut sends reports from [[Paris]] to [[Constantinople]] on politics and current events in France, but corresponds privately on other subjects including religion, and adds stories and anecdotes for diversion.<ref name="Betts"/> His observations range from those on political figures such as Richelieu and Mazarin to speculations on the status of women, advice about state policy, and major interventions in controversies about religious doctrine and their consequences.<ref>Paula R. Backscheider, Catherine Ingrassia, 2005, ''A companion to the eighteenth-century English novel and culture'', page 61</ref> His political position in the letters changes from that of liberal [[Catholic]] to that of a rationalistic [[Deism|Deist]].<ref name="Backscheider58"/>
== References == {{reflist}} {{commons category|Prints from Marana Espion turc at the Peace Palace Library}} Gian Carlo Roscioni, ''Sulle tracce dell'esploratore turco'', Milano, Rizzoli, 1992
==External links== *[[Internet Archive]] texts: **[https://archive.org/details/letterswrittenb00midggoog Letters writ by a Turkish spy, Volume 1, 26th edition, published 1770] **[https://archive.org/details/letterswrittenb02midggoog Letters writ by a Turkish spy, Volume 2, 26th edition, published 1770] **[https://archive.org/details/letterswrittenby03mara Letters writ by a Turkish spy, Volume 3, 26th edition, published 1770] **[https://archive.org/details/letterswrittenb04midggoog Letters writ by a Turkish spy, Volume 4, 26th edition, published 1770] **[https://archive.org/details/letterswrittenb05midggoog Letters writ by a Turkish spy, Volume 5, 26th edition, published 1770] **[https://archive.org/details/letterswrittenb03midggoog Letters writ by a Turkish spy, Volume 6, 26th edition, published 1770] **[https://archive.org/details/letterswrittenb01midggoog Letters writ by a Turkish spy, Volume 7, 26th edition, published 1770] **[https://archive.org/details/letterswrittenby08mara Letters writ by a Turkish spy, Volume 8, 26th edition, published 1770] *Ida Triglia,''L’Espion Turc on the Index Librorum Prohibitorum. Between Memory and Censorship'', http://unak.org.tr/upload/userfiles/files/UNAK2014bildiri.pdf

[[File:Hüfthose.jpg|thumb|right|A woman wearing a [[cropped top]] that bares the midriff]]In [[fashion]], the '''midriff''' is the human [[abdomen]]. The midriff is exposed when wearing a [[crop top]] or some forms of swimwear. The [[choli]]s worn by [[India]]n women exposes a thin section of midriff, usually 4 to 5 inches.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Vimla Menon|title=The modest saree has come full circle|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/columns/article315759.ece|accessdate=15 May 2015|publisher=The Indian Express|date=February 5, 2012}}</ref>
== Etymology == "Midriff" is an old term in the English language, coming into use before 1000 AD.<ref name="dictionary">[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Midriff "Midriff", Dictionary.com]</ref> In Old English it was written as "midhrif", with the old word "hrif" literally meaning stomach;<ref name="etymology">[http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=midriff "Midriff, the Online Etymology Dictionary]</ref> in Middle English it was "mydryf".<ref name="dictionary" /> The word fell into obsolescence after the 18th century.
The word was revived in 1941 by the fashion industry,<ref name="etymology" /> partly to avoid use of the word "belly" which genteel women considered undesirable in reference to their bodies, as it has connotations of [[obesity]]. ("Belly" was a word which was forbidden to be used in films by the [[Motion Picture Production Code|Hays Office]] censors. In the 1933 film ''[[42nd Street (film)|42nd Street]]'', for instance, in the song ''[[Shuffle Off to Buffalo]]'', [[Una Merkel]] is about to sing the lyric "with a shotgun at her belly", but stops after the "B" of "belly" and sings "tummy" instead.)
== Culture and history ==
=== Western culture ===
==== 1930s–1970s ==== [[File:Young women of Naples in swimsuit, Italy 1948.jpg|thumb|upright|right|A 1948 photo of [[Italians|Italian]] women in midriff-baring bikinis.]]In some cultures, exposure of the midriff is socially discouraged or even banned, and the [[Western culture]] has historically been hesitant in the use of midriff-baring styles. [[Bill Blass]] commented, "It is too difficult. Women will much more readily wear bare-back or plunging-neckline styles."<ref>{{cite news|last=BERNADINE MORRIS|title=Baring Midriffs: A Little, a Lot or Not?|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/11/30/news/baring-midriffs-a-little-a-lot-or-not.html|accessdate=20 March 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=November 30, 1993}}</ref> It was introduced to fashion in 1932 by [[Madeleine Vionnet]] when she offered an evening gown with strategically cut openings at the waist. Women's [[swimwear]] of the 1930s and 1940s incorporated increasing degrees of midriff exposure. Teen magazines of late 1940s and 1950s featured similar designs of midriff-baring suits and tops. However, midriff fashion was stated as only for beaches and informal events and considered indecent to be worn in public.<ref name="girl">{{cite book|last=Claudia Mitchell, Jacqueline Reid-Walsh|title=Girl Culture: Studying girl culture : a readers' guide Volume 1 of Girl Culture: An Encyclopedia|year=2008|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn= 9780313339097|page=702|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=arQy0v_PBx4C&pg=PA225&dq=cheerleader+midriff&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_wyAT--XCoTprQeL5NTrBQ&ved=0CEQQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=midriff&f=false}}</ref> However, exposure of the female midriff and [[navel]] was widely brought into everyday Western women's fashion in the 1960s' [[sexual revolution]] and later with the popularity of [[Halterneck|halter]]s, [[tube top]]s and [[crop top]]s in the 1970s. The [[cheerleading]] style fashions developing largely from the styles originating with the [[Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders]] in the early 1970s also played a crucial role for the popularity of midriff fashion at middle and high schools.<ref name="girl" /><ref>{{cite book|last=Tim Delaney, Tim Madigan|title=Sports: Why People Love Them!|year=2009|publisher=University Press of America|isbn= 9780761844891|page=248|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_leJMTGB3OoC&pg=PA148&dq=cheerleader+midriff&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_wyAT--XCoTprQeL5NTrBQ&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=midriff&f=false}}</ref>
==== 1980s–1990s ==== During the 1980s, pop star [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] appeared in bare midriff looks in her performances and music videos, which helped in spreading this fashion widely.<ref name="girl" /><ref>{{cite news|last=Julia Baird|title=What happened to Madonna|url=http://www.theage.com.au/lifestyle/what-happened-to-madonna-20120330-1w2s0.html|accessdate=8 April 2012|newspaper=The Age|date=April 1, 2012}}</ref> The popularity of the bare midriff continued well due to [[Low-rise (fashion)|low-rise]] fashion which started in the early 1990s when the British magazine ''[[The Face (magazine)|The Face]]'' in its March 1993 issue cover featured [[Kate Moss]] in [[low-rise jeans]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ziUAAAAAMBAJ&dq=New+York+Magazine%E2%80%8E+Navel&source=gbs_navlinks_s |title=Navel Mauvers |work=New York Magazine |date=10 May 1993 |page=26 |accessdate=11 August 2011}}</ref> At the same time, the wide acceptance of navel display in Western societies, [[navel piercing]]<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=hRHUOxramGEC&dq=navel+ring+saree&q=navel#v=snippet&q=navel&f=false Designing Clothes - Culture and Organization of the Fashion Industry - Veronica Manlow]</ref> and navel [[tattoos]]<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=if6_kBbJlCcC&pg=PA327&dq=drew+barrymore+navel+tattoo&hl=en&ei=1PVtTs7zJYHegQeBwY2tAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=navel&f=false Rhetorics of display - Lawrence J. Prelli]</ref> have become more common among young women. This raised the popularity of crop tops that expose the midriff and navel.<ref>[http://articles.nydailynews.com/2000-05-07/entertainment/18136533_1_tops-midriff-navel Cropped tops = midriff mania = abs-olutely erotic - ESTHER GROSS KREMER]</ref> During the 1990s, many designers adapted to the trend. One way of showing the midriff that has proved popular with designers is simply fastening a jacket or vest at the neckline and letting it fall freely. When the wearer moves there is a flash of skin, but nothing startling. Fashion designer [[Carolina Herrera (fashion designer)|Carolina Herrera]] told, "''the midriff doesn't have to be completely bare; a veil of chiffon over the midriff can look intriguing.''".<ref>{{cite news|last=BERNADINE MORRIS|title=Boldly or Demurely, The Midriff Bares Itself|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/15/news/boldly-or-demurely-the-midriff-bares-itself.html?src=pm|accessdate=20 March 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=December 15, 1992}}</ref>
==== 2010s ==== The bare midriff, with flat, toned abs, became the trend in Hollywood in the 2010s.<ref>{{cite web|last=Noelle Talmon|title=Celebrity Style Watch: Belly Baring Crop Tops|url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/Noelle_Talmon/2012/04/07/celebrity_style_watch_belly_baring_cro|publisher=Star Pulse|accessdate=8 April 2012}}</ref> In the Spring-Summer 2015 Haute Couture show by [[Chanel]] in Paris, midriff-baring tops were a main focus.<ref>{{cite news|title=Midriff 'the new cleavage' at latest Chanel show|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/lifestyle/midriff-the-new-cleavage-at-latest-chanel-show-1.2208471|accessdate=7 February 2015|work=CTV News|date=January 27, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Hannah Rochell|title=Belly Buttons Are Back - And At Chanel Couture (Of All Places!)|url=http://www.instyle.co.uk/fashion/news/belly-buttons-are-back-and-at-chanel-couture-of-all-places|website=instyle.co.uk|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref>
=== In US schools === Beginning in the late 1940s, school dress codes in the [[United States]] started to ban bare midriffs.<ref name="girl" /> Even today, many American [[secondary school]]s have dress codes dating back to the 1970s against attire that leaves the midriff exposed.<ref>{{cite web|last=Erin Shannon and Justin Graeber|title=VIDEO: School dress codes being tested by warm weather|url=http://www.wickedlocal.com/bridgewater/news/x586822468/VIDEO-School-dress-codes-being-tested-by-warm-weather#axzz1rTDd9gK4|work=GateHouse News Service|publisher=Wicked Local|accessdate=8 April 2012}}</ref> An example of a test that some schools apply is to have the student raise her arms if it is suspected that her shirt will expose her midriff. Although more tolerated with younger girls, older female students, especially those over 18 years of age, can be disciplined for exposing their navels on school campuses. As an example, the dress code of the [[Sherman Independent School District]] in Texas requires that "there must be no exposure of the midriff area or undergarments. The midriff area must not be seen while bending over, while standing, raising arms, and stretching."<ref name="sherman">{{cite web |url=http://www.ntxe-news.com/artman/publish/article_48025.shtml |title=Sherman Hih School Dress Code}}</ref>
In 2002, East Valley High School in [[Spokane Valley, Washington]] specified guidelines about inappropriate clothing in the school's student planner and handbook which includes "clothing that reveals the midriff".<ref>{{cite news|last=Virginia deLeon|title=Some schools draw the line below navel|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mWVWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jfIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5403,3078187&dq=navel+sexual&hl=en|accessdate=12 April 2012|newspaper=The Spokesman-Review|date=Sep 4, 2002}}</ref> In 2004, the Board of Education of [[Meriden, Connecticut]], brought a dress code that banned shirts, blouses that expose the top of the shoulders, [[haltertop]]s, [[Spaghetti strap|spaghetti tops]], and any clothing that exposed the waist, midriff or hips.<ref>{{cite news|last=Martin J. Waters|title=BOE sets student dress code:no hats, less skin|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Zc5IAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MQINAAAAIBAJ&pg=1425,2368885&dq=navel+expose&hl=en|accessdate=15 March 2012|newspaper=Record-Journal|date=Dec 15, 2004}}</ref>
=== Indian culture === [[File:Sherlyn Chopra at Playboy press meet 06.jpg|thumb|left|Actress and model [[Sherlyn Chopra]] in an Indian [[Sari]] that bares the midriff.]] [[File:Ameesha Patel still4.jpg|thumb|Indian actress [[Amisha Patel]] posing in a [[Gagra choli]] that bares the midriff]] Indian women have traditionally worn [[sari]]s that bare the midriff, especially [[South India]]n women.<ref name= Roshan>Alkazi, Roshan (1983) "Ancient Indian costume", Art Heritage;</ref><ref name= Ghurye>Ghurye (1951) "Indian costume", Popular book depot (Bombay)</ref> The gap on the midriff between sari and the choli presented the elegance of a woman’s graceful sway of her [[Gait (human)|gait]].<ref>{{cite news|last=D K Havanoor|title=The endangered sari|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/235022/endangered-sari.html|accessdate=18 March 2012|newspaper=Deccan Herald|date=17 March 2012}}</ref> A possible cultural justification is that in ancient Indian tradition, the navel of the God Vishnu the Protector is considered to be the center of the universe and the source of life.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=doQLZ21CGScC&dq=indian+sculpture+Navel&source=gbs_navlinks_s Principles of composition in Hindu sculpture: cave temple period - Alice Boner].</ref> From his navel a new world of the future emerges. This has been depicted in many ancient Indian sculptures as a lotus emerging from the navel on which God Brahma the Creator is seated.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=clUmKaWRFTkC&dq=indian+sculpture+Navel&source=gbs_navlinks_s Indian Sculpture: Circa 500 B.C.-A.D. 700 - Los Angeles County Museum of Art, Pratapaditya Pal].</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=fvKVDxcJoUC&vq=Navel&dq=natya+shastra+Navel&source=gbs_navlinks_s Indian Sculpture: 700-1800 - Los Angeles County Museum of Art, Pratapaditya Pal].</ref> Due to this the midriff is set to be left bare in a sari. Another reason could be the hot [[tropical]] climate of India. Rathi Vinay Jha, director general of the Fashion Design Council of India told, "''The bare midriff keeps you cool''".<ref>{{cite news|title=Don't tell Liz, but the sari's so out|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/apr/24/clothes.india|accessdate=20 March 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=24 April 2005}}</ref>
The sari adapts to a woman's body, rather than defining it, allowing for pregnancy and otherwise expanding girth. And in a culture where having enough to eat is not a given, rolls of fat around the midriff are a sign of prestige, rather than indulgence.<ref>{{cite news|last=Suzy Menkes|title=RUNWAYS; Naked Came The Midriff|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/05/29/style/runways-naked-came-the-midriff.html?pagewanted=2&src=pm|accessdate=20 March 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=May 29, 1994}}</ref> Dr.Torsekar, a [[paediatrician]] from India who works in [[Toledo, Ohio]], once told, "''It maybe hard for American women to imagine going to work with an exposed midriff, but for Indian women, the midriff is considered no more suggestive than the forearm.''"<ref>{{cite news|last=Tahree Lane|title=Sari|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=80BPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lgMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6996,1885944&dq=sari+choli&hl=en|accessdate=21 March 2012|newspaper=Toledo Blade|date=Mar 22, 1998}}</ref>
Other Indian communities that take midriff in their stride include the women from Rajasthan who leave the midriff exposed while wearing [[Gagra choli|Ghagra Cholis]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=W7c8TBQhoAIC&pg=PA148&dq=lehenga+saree&hl=en&ei=J1VjTvuNEZTUgAfvvuGsCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CGEQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q&f=false Social Science a Textbook in History for Class IX as per New Syllabus - FK Publications]</ref> However, these women often cover their heads with a [[Dupatta]]<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Lsai4v554d8C&dq=lehenga+saree&q=lehenga#v=onepage&q&f=false India - R.I.C. Publications]</ref> and even cover their faces in front of strangers, which enforces the belief that midriff-baring in India has a symbolic, almost mystical, association with birth and life and that the display is meant to emphasise the centrality of nature in the nurture role.<ref name="Beck">Beck, Brenda. (1976) The Symbolic Merger of Body, Space, and Cosmos in Hindu Tamil Nadu. Contributions to Indian Sociology 10(2): 213-43.</ref> In spite of it, some Indian philosophers gave opposition to exposing midriff in saris. They considered it to be a symbol of adultery.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=Ci7KTfzgD823tgeLgZ3fBw&ct=result&id=eFoOAAAAYAAJ&dq=fashion+expose+saree&q=midriff#search_anchor Sarvajna: the omniscient poet of Karnataka - Basavaraj Naikar].</ref> The only ornament accepted by the Hindu culture that can be worn in the midriff region are the [[waist chain]]s. They are considered to be a part of bridal [[jewellery]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=FOoCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA127&dq=waist+chain+sari&hl=en&ei=975uTo-dD9PG0AHD4MWACg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=sari%20chains&f=false Indianapolis Monthly - Jun 2004]</ref>
Due to modern fashion trends, along with saris, the midriff-revealing ghaghra cholis are also popular. Designer [[Manish Malhotra]]'s Fashion Week collections regularly highlight low [[Waistline (clothing)|waisted]] ghaghras accompanied by short cholis. Such ghagra cholis are more commonly worn by the [[Bollywood]] celebrities in films as well as in real life. For example, actress [[Malaika Arora Khan]] featured in midriff revealing ghagra choli without dupatta for the hit songs "[[Chaiyya Chaiyya]]" in [[Dil Se..]] (1998)<ref>[http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/bollywood-actress-showing-navel/1/140291.html Top 10 Navels in Cinema - India Today]</ref> and "Munni Badnam" in [[Dabangg]] (2010).<ref>[http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/bollywood-deepika-padukone-katrina-navel-look-is-new-cleavage-for-sexy-indian-women-and-re-emergence-of-sari/1/140273.html Rise of the Navel 'Bollywood navel fashion has led to re-emergence of sari' - India Today]</ref> Actress [[Priyanka Chopra]] featured in a [[Low-rise (fashion)|low rise]] ghagra choli designed by designer [[Ritu Kumar]] on the opening show of the HDIL India Couture Week 2008 held in [[Mumbai]].<ref>[http://movies.ndtv.com/GalleryDetails.aspx?category=Movies&id=2504&Section=Bollywood&pglctn=glrlstg&ch=9/19/2011%201:20:01%20PM Priyanka's fashionable walk - movies.ndtv.com]</ref><ref>[http://www.hindustantimes.com/photos-news/Photos-Fashion/HDILIndiaCoutureWeek/Article4-338357.aspx HDIL India Couture Week - hindustantimes.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111215175409/http://www.hindustantimes.com/photos-news/Photos-Fashion/HDILIndiaCoutureWeek/Article4-338357.aspx |date=2011-12-15 }}</ref><ref>[http://ibnlive.in.com/photogallery/963.html Priyanka dresses up for India Couture Week - IBNLive]</ref> At the Blenders Pride Fashion Tour 2011, she featured in a low rise ghagra choli designed by [[Neeta Lulla]].<ref>[http://www.sawfnews.com/Bollywood/67593.aspx Priyanka Chopra: Luscious in Lace at Blenders Pride Fashion Tour 2011 - sawfnews.com]</ref> Recently, actress [[Amisha Patel]] walked the ramp in a low rise green [[Gagra choli|Ghagra Choli]] designed by Rocky S at Aamby Valley City India Bridal Week 2011.<ref>[http://www.zeenatstyle.com/amisha-patel-lehenga-choli-rocky-s-aamby-valley-bridal-weel.html Amisha Patel In Green Lehenga Choli] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111016100111/http://www.zeenatstyle.com/amisha-patel-lehenga-choli-rocky-s-aamby-valley-bridal-weel.html |date=2011-10-16 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/stills/partiesnevents/Ameesha_Patel_walks_for_Rocky_S_at_Aamby_Valley_City_India_Bridal_Week_2011/index.html Ameesha Patel walks for Rocky S at Aamby Valley City India Bridal Week 2011 - BollywoodHungama.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111028022955/http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/stills/partiesnevents/Ameesha_Patel_walks_for_Rocky_S_at_Aamby_Valley_City_India_Bridal_Week_2011/index.html |date=2011-10-28 }}</ref>

{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} In [[archaeology]] and [[anthropology]] a '''mortuary house''' is any purpose-built structure, often resembling a normal dwelling in many ways, in which a dead body is buried.
Proper treatment and placing of the dead has always been of great concern to people around the world. While choice of burial location and treatment of the corpse usually depend on beliefs and ritual standards within a specific cultural context, they are as well of a strategic nature. Burial decisions are affected by cultural norms regarding the deceased’s age, gender, vertical or horizontal status and by the relationship of people to places and other people. Ideas concerning proper burial also apply to those who have been defunct for quite some time. Dead bodies have been exhumed, reburied and desecrated in order to redefine – elevate or degrade – the status of their owners, construct new affiliations, rewrite history and to retrieve or construct social memory.<ref>Weiss-Krejci, E. (2004). Mortuary representations of the noble house - a cross-cultural comparison between collective tombs of the ancient maya and dynastic europe. Journal of Social Archaeology, 4(3), 368-404.</ref>
Following the laying to rest of the deceased, who is often surrounded with [[grave goods]], an earthwork called a [[kurgan]] in Russian or [[tumulus|barrow]] in English is raised over the house and the structure left sealed.
The term has parallels with Christian [[sepulchre]]s which contain only one burial. Mortuary houses differ from [[mortuary enclosure]]s in size, design and in the latter's capacity for multiple burials.
==Origin== According to the Online Etymology Dictionary, the word [[mortuary]] derived in the early 14th century, from the word mortuarie, an Anglo-French word meaning "gift to a parish priest from a deceased parishioner"; from a Medieval Latin word mortuarium, a noun use of neuterof Late Latin adjective mortuarius "pertaining to the dead", from Latin mortuus, past participle of mori "to die". The meaning "place where bodies are kept temporarily" was first recorded in 1865, a euphemism for earlier deadhouse.<ref>{{mortuary. (n.d.). Online Etymology Dictionary. Retrieved March 01, 2015, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/mortuary.}}</ref>
== History == [[Philip Lieberman]] suggests that [[burial]] and [[mortuary]] housing may signify a "concern for the dead that transcends daily life."<ref>Philip Lieberman. (1991). Uniquely Human. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. {{ISBN|0-674-92183-6}}.</ref> It may be one of the earliest detectable forms of religious practice. Mortuary housing rituals can be detected back to the earliest days of human existence. Evidence suggests that the [[Neanderthals]] were the first [[Homo|human species]] to practice burial behavior and intentionally bury their dead, doing so in shallow graves along with stone tools and animal bones.<ref>Wilford, John Noble (December 16, 2013). "Neanderthals and the Dead". New York Times. Retrieved December 17, 2013.</ref> The earliest undisputed [[homo sapiens|human]] burial, discovered so far, dates back 100,000 years. Human skeletal remains stained with [[red ochre]] were discovered in the Skhul cave at [[Qafzeh]], Israel.
'''Egyptian Pyramids'''
Ancient Egypt is well known in their unique housing of the dead. The complex construction of chambers were both alluring and mysterious. The tombs represented as mortuary temples for the dead and the afterlife.
==Case Studies== '''Ballyveelish, Co. Tipperary Ireland''' <ref>Doody, M. "An Early Bronze Age Burial At Ballyveelish, Co. Tipperary." Tipperary Historical Journal. 1988.</ref>
The outline of a timber building was discovered by an archaeologist. From the circle of post holes and foundation trenches, the house was determined to be 7m x 5.1m. This structure was classified as a mortuary house, instead of dwelling, because of a lack of evidence of a hearth.
It is believed the mortuary house was built to serve a ceremonial function associated with the interment of human remains. Using [[radiocarbon dating]] it was determined this site was erected in the Bronze Age.

Japanese | budget = | gross = }} '''''Murder Collection V.1''''' is a 2009 American horror [[anthology film]] written and directed by [[Fred Vogel]], and co-written by Don Moore, Shelby Vogel and Jerami Cruise.{{cite book|author = Steve Jones|title = Torture Porn: Popular Horror after Saw|url = http://www.palgrave.com/us/book/9780230319417|accessdate = 25 February 2016|year = 2013|publisher = [[Palgrave Macmillan]]|isbn = 9781137317124|page = 174}}{{cite book|author = Alexandra Heller-Nicholas|title = Found Footage Horror Films: Fear and the Appearance of Reality|url = http://www.mcfarlandbooks.com/book-2.php?id=978-0-7864-7077-8|accessdate = 25 February 2016|year = 2014|publisher = [[McFarland & Company]]|isbn = 9780786470778|page = 194}} == Plot == The film's opening explains that in 1994 a [[web series]] called ''Murder'', which broadcast footage of actual deaths and acts of violence, appeared. After being active for four months, ''Murder'' was shut down by the authorities and had all of its content confiscated, though the website's host, a man known only as Balan, evaded capture. Now, years later, Balan has reemerged to share more clips that he has unearthed, while also offering commentary on people's obsession with death, the effect it has on them, and how accessible [[new media]] has made it. The series of videos is kicked off by Balan querying, "I ask you all... Why are you watching? Are you trying to find reality? Do you feel the need to be shocked? To witness something that human eyes shouldn't see? Murder is reality. Death comes when you least expect it. With what you are about to observe, you may question your own integrity. You will ask, could this happen to me? My answer to you is... Yes it can." * '''Bludgeoning:''' A drunk Russian man accidentally beats his teenage son to death in front of the son's [[webcam]]. * '''The Heist:''' A restaurant's security system records a robbery committed by four gunmen, who shoot a cashier in the head and a fleeing customer in the back. * '''The Cheat:''' In front of a stationary camera a man, Greg reminisces about how he met his wife, and about all of the good times that they shared, while a monitor in the background shows his wife having sex with someone else. The man leaves the room, and the monitor shows him barging in on his wife and her lover, hacking the former to death with an ax before cutting out her heart, which the wife had once said would always belong to him. * '''S&G:''' A parking lot security camera catches two people attacking a couple, beating the man with a baseball bat, and abducting the woman. * '''Broadway Rob:''' The distorted home movie of a pedophile, Broadway Rob who forces two gagged boys, Shawn and Ben clad in only their socks and underwear to dance with him. Shawn tackles Rob, fatally strangling and stabbing him. Shawn and Ben flee, leaving Rob's dead body behind. * '''Execution:''' A muffled black and white [[camcorder]] video of a hooded and masked group (possibly a [[cult]] or a gang) executing a man via decapitation in front of a woman, whom they taunt with the severed head before shooting her. * '''ATM:''' A man is mugged and killed at an [[Automated teller machine|ATM]]. * '''Autopsy:''' Japanese autopsy footage of a woman who was shot in the mouth, with the bullet exiting the top of her skull. The coroner eventually kicks the cameraman out due to his unprofessional antics and inattentiveness. * '''Bullied:''' A trio of drunks use a camcorder to record themselves taking a man out into the woods under the pretense of initiating him into their group. The three bully and humiliate the man and, during a scuffle, one of them accidentally knocks him onto the knife another was holding. The trio panic and bicker, and the camera is dropped when a fight breaks out over whether they should go for help. * '''Homecoming:''' A building security camera records two figures [[Garrote|garroting]] a man. * '''Ransom:''' A deteriorated series of [[ransom]] videos depict three men brutalizing a [[Senate|senator's]] daughter, who eventually dies due to the severity of her injuries. After the last clip, Balan delivers the closing statement, "You realize now it's everywhere. Death casts a shadow on all our faces. The new media shines light on dank crevasses, revealing moral decay and broken experiences that are better left beyond the pale. Goosebumps explode on my skin with every clip we watch. I feel it now more than ever. How do you feel?" == Cast == * Opening Credits: ** Mary Shore as The Victim * Bludgeoning: ** Daniel V. Klein as Father ** Damien A. Maruscak as Son * The Heist: ** Sonny L. Shannon as The Manager ** Matthew Plutko as The Cook ** Shelby Lyn Vogel as The Tender ** Sean L. Joyce as The Sprinter ** Rebecca Tronzo as Topaz ** Eric Schwartzbauer as Leon ** Aziza as Madam Green ** Don Moore as G.A. Moore ** Aymee Peake as April ** Chris Krzysik as The Barback ** Mike Driscoll as The Gent ** Michael Pacinda as PKC ** Anthony Matthews as PKC ** [[Fred Vogel]] as PKC ** Jerami Cruise as PKC * The Cheat: ** Jason Schneeberger as Greg ** Lexi Jade as The Adulteress ** Scott Burke as The Adulterer * S&G: ** Shelby Lyn Vogel as Lyn ** Jason Kollat as Michael ** Jim Kollat as Jim ** Anthony Matthews as Anthony * Broadway Rob: ** Tom Smith as Broadway Rob ** Steve Schofield as Shawn ** Tim Schofield as Ben * Execution: ** Jerami Cruise as The Executioner ** John Viss as Chuck ** John Ross as The Handler ** Aymee Peake as Jill ** Will Guffey as Smith ** Fred Vogel as Black * ATM: ** Don Moore as The Banker ** Douglass Bell as Ace * Autopsy: ** Dorian K. Arnold as The Doctor * Bullied: ** Adrian Alexander D'Amico as Cope ** Dave Dalessandro as Jake ** Michael Witherel as Castle ** Jay Mattingly as Gromer * Homecoming: ** Stephen Vogel as Eddie the Rat ** Kai Peter as Zack ** Jason Spence as Hudson * Ransom: ** Harvey Daniels as Jovan ** [[Ruckus (wrestler)|Claude Marrow]] as Sidel ** Clint Brown as Deron ** Lacey Fleming as Ginnifer Mitchell == Reception == Ryan Doom of [[JoBlo.com|Arrow in the Head]] gave ''Murder Collection V.1'' a 2/4 and wrote, "In the end, I think it's an interesting exercise, but I don't know if it makes it a good movie. This isn't the type of film that I suspect most viewers would revisit often, if at all. Instead, it's just an experiment that people will dig or not, depending on how much violence and gore they can stomach without a story for context. While it captivated me at times with certain segments, others seemed unnecessary or overdone. But maybe that's just me".{{cite web|url = http://www.joblo.com/horror-movies/dvd-reviews/murder-collection-v1|title = ''Murder Collection V.1''|last = Doom|first = Ryan|publisher = Arrow in the Head|date = |website = joblo.com|accessdate = 25 February 2016}} Horror News's Jay Alan praised the special effects, also calling the acting "convincingly believable for the most part" and writing, "As much as the film focuses on the graphic and dark nature of death, it also delves into the human psyche and personalities of the characters within the little given time shown."{{cite web|url = http://horrornews.net/30431/film-review-murder-collection-vol-1-2009/|title = Film Review: ''Murder Collection Vol. 1'' (2009)|last = Alan|first = Jay|publisher = Horror News|date = 2 November
